importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The AWS outage occurred on Monday, October 20, 2025, at approximately 07:11 GMT, marking a critical moment when widespread digital services failed due to a technical error in AWS infrastructure.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The outage began at 07:11 GMT and was resolved by 10:11 GMT, highlighting a four-hour window during which critical internet services across multiple domains were disrupted.

keyTakeAways: The outage was caused by a technical error during an update to DynamoDB’s API, which disrupted the Domain Name System (DNS), preventing apps from finding server addresses.
The root cause was human error, not a cyberattack or malicious activity, as confirmed by cybersecurity expert Bryson Bort of Scythe.

The failure triggered a cascade effect, affecting 113 AWS services including major platforms like Snapchat, Pinterest, WhatsApp, Zoom, Roblox, Fortnite, Apple TV, Starbucks, and financial apps like Venmo.
AWS, the world’s largest cloud provider, operates a critical infrastructure that underpins much of modern digital life, making such outages highly impactful.
While the outage was contained and resolved within hours, it exposed the fragility of digital ecosystems dependent on centralized cloud services.
Despite the disruption, AWS was able to restore services quickly, and experts believe user migration away from AWS is unlikely due to its dominant market position (30% share).

namedEntities.name: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major cloud computing platform that provides infrastructure and services for hosting websites, apps, and data storage.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: AWS is the largest cloud service provider globally, and its outage disrupted a vast array of internet services, illustrating its critical role in modern digital infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: DynamoDB
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cloud database service offered by AWS that stores user data and other critical information for online platforms.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The update error to DynamoDB’s API caused a DNS failure, which in turn caused widespread outages across dependent apps and services.

namedEntities.name: Domain Name System (DNS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A system that translates website names into IP addresses, acting like the internet’s phone book.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The DNS error prevented apps from connecting to servers, directly causing the outage and demonstrating how foundational internet infrastructure can be compromised by technical flaws.

namedEntities.name: Snapchat
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A social media and messaging app that relies on cloud infrastructure.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Snapchat experienced outages during the AWS downtime, showing how cloud-dependent apps are vulnerable to infrastructure failures.

namedEntities.name: Pinterest
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A social media platform that stores and recommends visual content, hosted on cloud services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pinterest went offline during the AWS outage, highlighting how even social media apps depend on stable cloud infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: WhatsApp
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A messaging app that runs on cloud-based services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WhatsApp users reported connectivity issues, indicating how real-time communication tools are deeply tied to cloud services.

namedEntities.name: Zoom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A video conferencing platform that relies on cloud computing.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zoom experienced disruptions, showing how remote work and communication tools are vulnerable during cloud outages.

namedEntities.name: Roblox
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An online gaming platform hosted on AWS infrastructure.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Roblox went offline, demonstrating how gaming platforms depend on cloud services for operation.

namedEntities.name: Fortnite
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A popular online video game hosted on cloud infrastructure.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Fortnite became inaccessible, illustrating how real-time gaming services are susceptible to cloud outages.

namedEntities.name: Apple TV
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A digital media platform that uses AWS for backend services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Apple TV faced outages, showing how media platforms are dependent on cloud infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: Starbucks
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global retail chain with digital services hosted on AWS.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Starbucks customers reported issues, indicating that even physical retail brands rely on cloud systems for operations.

namedEntities.name: Venmo
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A financial app that relies on cloud-based transaction processing.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Venmo experienced service interruptions, highlighting the vulnerability of financial services to cloud failures.

namedEntities.name: Duolingo
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A language-learning app that uses cloud infrastructure.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Duolingo reported errors, demonstrating how educational tools depend on stable cloud services.

namedEntities.name: Canva
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A creative tool that relies on cloud storage and processing.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Canva experienced outages, showing how creative applications are affected by cloud disruptions.

namedEntities.name: The Associated Press
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major news agency that uses cloud services for content delivery.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The AP was among media organizations impacted, indicating that journalism and content platforms rely on cloud infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: The New York Times
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major media organization dependent on cloud-based platforms.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Times experienced issues, showing how news media rely on cloud systems for operations.

namedEntities.name: The Wall Street Journal
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major financial news outlet using cloud services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WSJ was affected, illustrating the sensitivity of financial media to infrastructure outages.

namedEntities.name: Coinbase
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cryptocurrency exchange that uses AWS for backend operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Coinbase reported outages, showing how fintech services depend on cloud infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: Perplexity
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An AI company that uses cloud services to power its models.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Perplexity experienced outages, demonstrating the fragility of AI services reliant on cloud computing.

namedEntities.name: Delta Airlines
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major U.S. airline that uses cloud systems for operations and customer services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Delta reported issues, indicating how transportation services depend on cloud infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: United Airlines
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. airline with cloud-dependent operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: United also reported outages, showing how airlines rely on cloud systems for customer-facing services.

namedEntities.name: Ring
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A smart home device that uses cloud services for remote access and monitoring.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Users reported that Ring doorbells stopped working, showing how smart home devices are dependent on cloud connectivity.

namedEntities.name: Alexa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A voice-activated smart assistant from Amazon that relies on cloud processing.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Alexa speakers failed to respond, demonstrating how consumer IoT devices depend on cloud services.

namedEntities.name: Etsy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An online marketplace that relies on cloud infrastructure.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Etsy experienced technical issues, showing how e-commerce platforms are vulnerable to cloud outages.

namedEntities.name: Joshua Mahony
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief market analyst at Scope Markets, who commented on the impact of the AWS outage.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Mahony provided expert insight into the market resilience of AWS, noting that user migration is unlikely due to AWS’s dominance.

namedEntities.name: Bryson Bort
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: CEO of Scythe, a cybersecurity company, who addressed the cause of the outage.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bort clarified that the outage was due to human error, not a cyberattack, reinforcing the common cause of such incidents.

summaryOfNewsArticle: An outage at Amazon Web Services (AWS), caused by a technical error during an update to DynamoDB’s API that disrupted the Domain Name System (DNS), led to widespread failures across 113 AWS services. This included major platforms such as Snapchat, Pinterest, WhatsApp, Zoom, Roblox, Fortnite, Venmo, Duolingo, Apple TV, Starbucks, and financial and media services like Coinbase, The New York Times, and The Wall Street Journal. The incident affected smart home devices like Ring and Alexa, highlighting the deep dependence of modern digital life on cloud infrastructure. Experts concluded the issue stemmed from human error, not a cyberattack, and emphasized that despite the scale of disruption, AWS’s market dominance and rapid recovery make such outages manageable and unlikely to trigger significant user migration.
title: What caused Amazon’s AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?
